title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 8 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ecclesiastes chapter 8 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 8 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ecclesiastes Chapter 8.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:1, what effect does a man's wisdom have on his face?
options: It maketh his face to shine
It maketh his face to frown
It maketh his face to blush
It maketh his face to grow dark
questions.correctAnswer: It maketh his face to shine
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:1 says, 'a man's wisdom maketh his face to shine,' showing the positive effect of wisdom.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 8:2 counsel us to keep?
questions.correctAnswer: The king's commandment
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:2 says, 'I counsel thee to keep the king's commandment,' advising respect for the king's orders.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:4, where is power found?
options: Where the word of a king is
In the hands of the people
In the hearts of the wise
questions.correctAnswer: Where the word of a king is
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states, 'Where the word of a king is, there is power,' emphasizing royal authority.

questions.question: What does a wise man's heart discern according to Ecclesiastes 8:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Both time and judgment
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:5 says, 'a wise man's heart discerneth both time and judgment,' highlighting wisdom in timing and decisions.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 8:8 says that man has power over the spirit to retain it.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:8 states, 'There is no man that hath power over the spirit to retain the spirit,' meaning no one controls the spirit.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 8:10 say about the wicked who are buried?
options: They are forgotten in the city where they had done evil
They are celebrated by the people
questions.correctAnswer: They are forgotten in the city where they had done evil
questions.explanation: Verse 10 describes the wicked being forgotten in the city where they sinned, showing vanity in their legacy.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:11, why do people continue to do evil?
options: Because sentence against evil is not executed speedily
Because they are forced by others
Because they do not know right from wrong
questions.correctAnswer: Because sentence against evil is not executed speedily
questions.explanation: Verse 11 says the delay in punishment encourages people to do evil.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 8:12 states that it will be well with those who fear God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 12 confirms that those who fear God will have well-being.

questions.question: What is said about the days of the wicked in Ecclesiastes 8:13?
options: Their days are as a shadow
Their days are long and prosperous
Their days are full of joy
Their days are recorded in the book of life
questions.correctAnswer: Their days are as a shadow
questions.explanation: Verse 13 describes the wicked's days as fleeting like a shadow.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Ecclesiastes 8:15: 'Then I commended mirth, because a man hath no better thing under the sun, than to ______.'
options: eat, and to drink, and to be merry
questions.correctAnswer: eat, and to drink, and to be merry
questions.explanation: Verse 15 says the best thing is to 'eat, and to drink, and to be merry,' commending joy in life.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:6, what causes great misery upon man?
options: Because to every purpose there is time and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Because to every purpose there is time and judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states that the existence of time and judgment results in great misery.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 8:9 mentions a time when one man rules over another to his own hurt.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 9 refers to a time when one man rules another to his own detriment.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 8:3 advise about leaving the king's presence?
options: Be not hasty to go out of his sight
questions.correctAnswer: Be not hasty to go out of his sight
questions.explanation: Verse 3 counsels not to be quick to leave the king's presence, showing respect.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:7, why does man not know what shall be?
options: For who can tell him when it shall be?
questions.correctAnswer: For who can tell him when it shall be?
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states man does not know the future because no one can tell him when it will occur.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:17, can man find out all the work done under the sun?
options: No, even the wise cannot find it all out
Only the foolish can understand it
questions.correctAnswer: No, even the wise cannot find it all out
questions.explanation: Verse 17 says that though one labors to seek it out, man cannot find all the work done under the sun.

medium.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 8 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ecclesiastes Chapter 8 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 8 teach us about wisdom in daily life?
options: Wisdom makes a man's face shine and changes his boldness
Wisdom prevents all troubles and suffering
Wisdom means never obeying earthly authorities
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom makes a man's face shine and changes his boldness
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:1 highlights that a man's wisdom causes his face to shine and changes the boldness of his face, illustrating the visible impact of wisdom. This teaches the value of wisdom in character and demeanor. Other verses such as 8:5 and 8:16 also emphasize discerning time and judgment and seeking wisdom.

questions.question: What counsel does the passage give about obeying authorities while honoring God?
options: Keep the king's commandment because of God's oath
Disobey the king if it conflicts with personal desires
Ignore earthly kings and focus only on God
questions.correctAnswer: Keep the king's commandment because of God's oath
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:2 advises obedience to the king's commandment in view of the oath of God, teaching a balance of respecting earthly authority while honoring God. Verses 8:3 and 8:4 further emphasize not being hasty or disputing the king’s power.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8, what should a wise person be discerning about?
questions.correctAnswer: Both time and judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 8:5 states that a wise man's heart discerns both time and judgment, teaching us the importance of recognizing the right timing and making sound decisions in life. This helps in practical Christian living with integrity and patience.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 8 describe man's knowledge of the future?
options: Man does not know what will happen and cannot tell when it shall be
Man can predict the future accurately through wisdom
Man controls his future through his actions
The future is fully revealed in dreams
questions.correctAnswer: Man does not know what will happen and cannot tell when it shall be
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:7 explains that man does not know what will be and cannot tell when it shall be, reminding believers of humility and trust in God's sovereignty rather than presuming control over the future.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 8 say about the power of man over death and the spirit?
options: No man has power to retain the spirit or power at the day of death
Some men can conquer death through wisdom
Death can be delayed by righteous living
Spirit and life are controlled by human effort
questions.correctAnswer: No man has power to retain the spirit or power at the day of death
questions.explanation: Verse 8:8 teaches that no one has power over the spirit to retain it, nor power in the day of death, emphasizing human limitation and the inevitability of death, which calls for faith and humility in God's plan.

questions.question: What practical lesson about leadership and its effects is taught in Ecclesiastes 8?
options: Sometimes one man rules over another to his own hurt
Leaders always bring blessing and peace
Leadership is always fair and just
One should strive to avoid leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Sometimes one man rules over another to his own hurt
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:9 observes that there are times when one man rules over another to his own hurt, teaching that human authority can cause harm and that believers must navigate leadership with wisdom and patience.

questions.question: How does the chapter describe the fate of the wicked who are buried after their deeds?
options: They are forgotten in the city where they did evil; this is vanity
They are remembered as examples of evil
They receive honor despite their wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: They are forgotten in the city where they did evil; this is vanity
questions.explanation: Verse 8:10 states that wicked persons are buried and forgotten in the city where they acted wickedly, illustrating the vanity of evil and the fleeting nature of worldly recognition, encouraging believers to focus on eternal values.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8, what happens when punishment for evil is not executed quickly?
options: The hearts of people are fully set to do evil
People repent and turn from evil
Evil is diminished in the land
Justice is still effective regardless of timing
questions.correctAnswer: The hearts of people are fully set to do evil
questions.explanation: In verse 8:11, the delay of punishment leads to people being emboldened to do evil, teaching the importance of timely justice and encouraging believers to continue living righteously despite delays in human justice.

questions.question: What assurance does Ecclesiastes 8 provide to those who fear God?
options: It shall be well with them, even if sinners prosper temporarily
They will be wealthy and honored
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be well with them, even if sinners prosper temporarily
questions.explanation: Verse 8:12 assures that though sinners do evil many times and live long, it shall be well with those who fear God, encouraging faithfulness and reverence despite worldly injustice.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ecclesiastes 8:13 teaches that it shall not be well with the wicked, neither shall he prolong his days, which are as a _____.
questions.correctAnswer: shadow
questions.explanation: Verse 8:13 uses the metaphor of days being as a shadow to describe the fleeting and uncertain life of the wicked, warning believers about the consequences of fearing not God.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 8 describe the apparent injustice experienced by both the righteous and the wicked?
options: There is vanity in that just men suffer as the wicked do, and wicked men suffer as the righteous do
The righteous always prosper and the wicked always suffer
Justice is always clear and immediate
questions.correctAnswer: There is vanity in that just men suffer as the wicked do, and wicked men suffer as the righteous do
questions.explanation: Verse 8:14 acknowledges the perplexing reality that both righteous and wicked experience outcomes contrary to their deeds, calling believers to trust God beyond immediate circumstances.

questions.question: What practical advice does Ecclesiastes 8 give about enjoying life amid uncertainties?
options: Commend mirth: eat, drink, and be merry under the life God gives
Avoid all pleasure and focus solely on work
Save all resources for the afterlife
Ignore earthly gifts and suffer quietly
questions.correctAnswer: Commend mirth: eat, drink, and be merry under the life God gives
questions.explanation: Verse 8:15 commends rejoicing and enjoying the simple gifts of life—eating, drinking, and being merry—as the best under the sun, teaching contentment and gratitude in God's provision.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8, what is a challenge even for the wise when seeking to understand God's work?
options: Man cannot find out all the work done under the sun despite labor and wisdom
All things are easily understood by the wise
The wicked understand God's work better than the righteous
God reveals every detail to those who seek diligently
questions.correctAnswer: Man cannot find out all the work done under the sun despite labor and wisdom
questions.explanation: Verses 8:16-17 teach that although a man may labor and be wise, he cannot fully discover God's work done under the sun, encouraging humility and trust in God's mysterious providence.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 8 teaches that one should be quick to confront and oppose the king's decisions.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 8:3 advises not to be hasty to leave the king's presence or stand in an evil thing, recognizing the king does what pleases him, teaching patience and respect for authority.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 8 states that wickedness will ultimately deliver those who practice it.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 8:8 declares that wickedness will not deliver those given to it, emphasizing the futility of evil and encouraging believers to live righteously.

hard.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 8 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ecclesiastes Chapter 8.

questions.question: What does the wise man's face do according to Ecclesiastes 8:1, and how might this reflect a cultural understanding of wisdom in the ancient Near East?
questions.correctAnswer: It shines and shows boldness
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:1 states that a man's wisdom makes his face to shine and the boldness of his face shall be changed, reflecting the ancient Near Eastern idea that wisdom manifests outwardly in demeanor and countenance.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:2, what is the advised attitude toward the king's commandment?
options: Keep the king's commandment in regard of the oath of God
Disregard the king's commandment for personal freedom
Only obey when it suits personal interests
questions.correctAnswer: Keep the king's commandment in regard of the oath of God
questions.explanation: The verse advises to keep the king's commandment, emphasizing respect for authority as part of honoring the divine oath, showing the intertwining of royal and divine authority.

questions.question: Why does Ecclesiastes 8 caution against hastily leaving the king's presence in verse 3?
options: Because the king does whatever pleases him
Because the king is always just
Because the king needs constant advice
questions.correctAnswer: Because the king does whatever pleases him
questions.explanation: Verse 3 warns not to be hasty to leave the king’s sight since he does whatever pleases him, highlighting the unpredictability of royal power in ancient Near Eastern courts.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 8:4 imply about the power of a king's word?
options: Where the word of a king is, there is power
The king's word is often ignored
The king's word is subject to debate
The word of a king is weak
questions.correctAnswer: Where the word of a king is, there is power
questions.explanation: The verse underscores the absolute authority of the king, reflecting the political realities of monarchies where royal decrees are decisive and unquestioned.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 8:5 states 'a wise man's heart discerneth both time and judgment.' What literary device is primarily used here?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse employs parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, to emphasize the wise man's discernment regarding proper timing and wise decision-making.

questions.question: What is the reason given for man's great misery in Ecclesiastes 8:6?
options: Because there is a time and judgment for every purpose
Because men do not work hard enough
questions.correctAnswer: Because there is a time and judgment for every purpose
questions.explanation: Verse 6 connects the inevitability of time and judgment to human misery, reflecting the theme of human limitation in controlling destiny.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 8:8 reveal about human power over life and death?
options: No man has power to retain the spirit or overcome death
Men can delay death by wisdom
Spirit can be controlled by prayer
Only kings have power over death
questions.correctAnswer: No man has power to retain the spirit or overcome death
questions.explanation: The verse teaches that death is inevitable and uncontrolled by human power, aligning with broader biblical themes about mortality.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 8:10 suggests that wicked people are always remembered and honored in their cities.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:10 says the wicked are buried and forgotten in the city where they did evil, highlighting the vanity and fleeting nature of wickedness.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 8:11 explain the persistence of evil deeds among people?
options: Because sentence against evil is not executed speedily
Because good men fail to act
questions.correctAnswer: Because sentence against evil is not executed speedily
questions.explanation: The verse reveals a sociological insight: delayed justice emboldens people to continue evil acts.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:12, what is the destiny of those who fear God despite sinners prospering?
options: It shall be well with them
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be well with them
questions.explanation: This verse contrasts the fate of the righteous who fear God with that of sinners, affirming divine justice ultimately favors the godly.

questions.question: What literary theme is strongly expressed in Ecclesiastes 8:14 regarding the fate of the just and the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Vanity of life
questions.explanation: The verse reflects on the apparent injustice in life where just men suffer and wicked men prosper, emphasizing the theme of life's vanity.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 8:15, what activity is commended as the best under the sun, and how does this reflect Hebrew wisdom literature's approach to life's meaning?
options: To eat, drink, and be merry
questions.correctAnswer: To eat, drink, and be merry
questions.explanation: The verse recommends enjoying simple pleasures, a hallmark of wisdom literature's pragmatic approach to finding contentment amid life's uncertainties.

questions.question: What is the significance of the restless figure in Ecclesiastes 8:16 who neither sees day nor night?
questions.correctAnswer: Represents ceaseless labor or worry
questions.explanation: This figure illustrates human toil and anxiety, emphasizing the futility of trying to understand all that happens under the sun.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 8:17 states that even a wise man cannot find out all the work done under the sun. What theological theme does this highlight?
questions.correctAnswer: Human limitation and divine mystery
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes that despite wisdom, humans cannot fully comprehend God's work, underscoring the mystery of divine providence.

questions.question: How does the theme of time and judgment in Ecclesiastes 8:6 relate to the broader biblical concept of 'appointed times' found in Ecclesiastes and other books like Daniel?
options: It shows that all events occur in God's appointed time
It denies that time has any meaning
It promotes human control over events
It suggests time is cyclical without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that all events occur in God's appointed time
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:6 reflects the biblical theme that events unfold according to divine timing, paralleling passages such as Daniel 2:21 on God's sovereignty over time.

theological.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 8 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ecclesiastes Chapter 8 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:1, what effect does a man's wisdom have on his face?
options: It makes his face to shine
It causes his face to frown
It causes his face to blush
questions.correctAnswer: It makes his face to shine
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:1 states that a man's wisdom maketh his face to shine, indicating the illuminating effect of wisdom. Similarly, Proverbs 16:15 notes the light of a king's face brings joy, and Psalm 34:5 mentions the face shining with joy. Jesus in Matthew 5:16 teaches letting your light shine before men, reflecting godly wisdom.

questions.question: What counsel does the author give regarding the king's commandment in Ecclesiastes 8:2?
options: To keep the king's commandment because of the oath of God
To rebel against the king's commandment
questions.correctAnswer: To keep the king's commandment because of the oath of God
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:2 advises obedience to the king's commandment in light of God's oath, highlighting respect for earthly authority as ordained by God (Romans 13:1-2; 1 Peter 2:13-17). This reflects biblical teaching on submission to governing authorities as part of reverence for God.

questions.question: What warning is given in Ecclesiastes 8:3 about leaving the king's presence hastily?
options: Do not be hasty to go out of his sight
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be hasty to go out of his sight
questions.explanation: The verse warns not to be hasty in leaving the king's presence because he does whatever pleases him, implying caution and respect (Ecclesiastes 8:3). This aligns with Proverbs 24:21-22 about fearing the king and God's wrath, and Romans 13:1 about submitting to authority.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 8:4 say about the word of a king?
options: Where the word of a king is, there is power
The king's word can be questioned
The king's word is often ignored
questions.correctAnswer: Where the word of a king is, there is power
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:4 states that the king's word carries power, emphasizing the authority of rulers as established by God (Romans 13:1). This reflects biblical recognition of God's sovereignty over earthly powers (Daniel 2:21; Proverbs 21:1).

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:5, what will a wise man's heart discern?
questions.correctAnswer: Both time and judgment
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:5 teaches that a wise man's heart discerns both time and judgment, reflecting discernment in decision-making. James 1:5 encourages asking God for wisdom, and Proverbs 3:5-6 highlights trust in the Lord’s guidance, which includes understanding timing and judgment.

questions.question: Why is the misery of man great upon him, according to Ecclesiastes 8:6?
options: Because to every purpose there is time and judgment
Because man controls his own destiny
questions.correctAnswer: Because to every purpose there is time and judgment
questions.explanation: The verse explains that the certainty of time and judgment causes great misery, reflecting the human condition under divine sovereignty (Ecclesiastes 8:6). This corresponds with Hebrews 9:27 on judgment after death and Romans 14:12 concerning personal accountability.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ecclesiastes 8:8 states, 'There is no man that hath power over the _____ to retain the spirit.'
questions.correctAnswer: spirit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:8 declares that no one can retain the spirit (life) at death, emphasizing human powerlessness over life and death. This aligns with Job 34:14-15 and Psalm 146:4 on the spirit's departure at death, and Hebrews 9:27 on the inevitability of death.

questions.question: What observation does the author make in Ecclesiastes 8:9 about one man ruling over another?
options: One man rules over another to his own hurt
One man rules over another with justice
One man rules over another with wisdom
One man rules over another to bring peace
questions.correctAnswer: One man rules over another to his own hurt
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:9 notes that sometimes rulers act to their own harm, revealing the vanity and injustice in earthly authority. This is echoed in Psalm 72:4 regarding unjust rulers and Romans 13:3-4 which calls rulers God's servants for good but warns of judgment for evil deeds.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:10, what is said about the wicked who are buried?
options: They are forgotten in the city where they had done evil
They are honored for their deeds
questions.correctAnswer: They are forgotten in the city where they had done evil
questions.explanation: The verse describes that the wicked are buried and forgotten despite their evil actions, illustrating the vanity of wickedness (Ecclesiastes 8:10). This contrasts with Proverbs 10:7 on the memory of the righteous, and Psalm 37:1-2 which encourages not fretting over evildoers.

questions.question: What consequence does Ecclesiastes 8:11 associate with the delay of judgment against evil deeds?
options: The heart of men is fully set in them to do evil
questions.correctAnswer: The heart of men is fully set in them to do evil
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:11 teaches that delayed judgment emboldens people to continue doing evil. This reflects biblical warnings in Romans 1:32 and Proverbs 29:1 about persistence in sin due to lack of immediate consequences.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 8:12 contrasts the fate of sinners and those who fear God. What is said about those who fear God?
options: It shall be well with them
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be well with them
questions.explanation: The verse affirms that those who fear God will ultimately fare well, despite the sinner's temporary success. This aligns with Psalm 112:6, Proverbs 19:23, and Matthew 10:28 emphasizing God's care for the righteous and final reward.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 8:13 say about the wicked who do not fear God?
options: They shall not be well and will have days as a shadow
They will be honored by men
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be well and will have days as a shadow
questions.explanation: The verse states that the wicked who do not fear God will not prosper and their days are fleeting, like a shadow. This is consistent with Psalm 37:1-2, Job 14:2, and James 4:14 emphasizing the transience of wicked prosperity.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 8:14 describes a vanity involving just and wicked men. What is this vanity?
options: Just men suffer according to wicked works, and wicked men suffer according to righteous works
Just men always prosper and wicked men always suffer
questions.correctAnswer: Just men suffer according to wicked works, and wicked men suffer according to righteous works
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the apparent injustice where righteous people suffer due to wickedness, and vice versa, calling it vanity. This echoes Job 21:7-13 and Romans 8:28, which affirm God's ultimate justice despite present suffering.

questions.question: What does the author commend in Ecclesiastes 8:15 as the best thing under the sun?
options: To eat, drink, and be merry
questions.correctAnswer: To eat, drink, and be merry
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 8:15 commends mirth through eating, drinking, and being merry as the best under the sun, recognizing enjoyment of God's gifts amid life's vanity. This aligns with 1 Timothy 6:17 and Psalm 104:14-15 which celebrate God's provision.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 8:16, what is said about those who neither see day nor night in sleep?
options: There is one who neither day nor night seeth sleep with his eyes
Everyone sleeps both day and night
questions.correctAnswer: There is one who neither day nor night seeth sleep with his eyes
questions.explanation: The verse mentions a person who does not see sleep day or night, indicating restless labor or worry. This reflects Psalm 127:2 on labor without rest and Proverbs 3:24 about peaceful sleep granted by God.
